At the 1912 Salon d'Automne an architectural installation was exhibited that quickly became known as Maison Cubiste (Cubist House), signed Raymond Duchamp-Villon and André Mare along with a group of collaborators. Metzinger and Gleizes in Du "Cubisme", written during the assemblage of the "Maison Cubiste", wrote about the autonomous nature of art, stressing the point that decorative considerations should not govern the spirit of art. Decorative work, to them, was the "antithesis of the picture". "The true picture" wrote Metzinger and Gleizes, "bears its raison d'être within itself. It can be moved from a church to a drawing-room, from a museum to a study. Essentially independent, necessarily complete, it need not immediately satisfy the mind: on the contrary, it should lead it, little by little, towards the fictitious depths in which the coordinative light resides. It does not harmonize with this or that ensemble; it harmonizes with things in general, with the universe: it is an organism...". "Mare's ensembles were accepted as frames for Cubist works because they allowed paintings and sculptures their independence", writes Christopher Green, "creating a play of contrasts, hence the involvement not only of Gleizes and Metzinger themselves, but of Marie Laurencin, the Duchamp brothers (Raymond Duchamp-Villon designed the facade) and Mare's old friends Léger and Roger La Fresnaye". La Maison Cubiste was a fully furnished house, with a staircase, wrought iron banisters, a living room—the Salon Bourgeois, where paintings by Marcel Duchamp, Metzinger (Woman with a Fan), Gleizes, Laurencin and Léger were hung—and a bedroom. It was an example of L'art décoratif, a home within which Cubist art could be displayed in the comfort and style of modern, bourgeois life. Spectators at the Salon d'Automne passed through the full-scale 10-by-3-meter plaster model of the ground floor of the facade, designed by Duchamp-Villon. This architectural installation was subsequently exhibited at the 1913 Armory Show, New York, Chicago and Boston, listed in the catalogue of the New York exhibit as Raymond Duchamp-Villon, number 609, and entitled "Facade architectural, plaster" (Façade architecturale).

Some rock musicians today use mandolins, often single-stringed electric models rather than double-stringed acoustic mandolins. One example is Tim Brennan of the Irish-American punk rock band Dropkick Murphys. In addition to electric guitar, bass, and drums, the band uses several instruments associated with traditional Celtic music, including mandolin, tin whistle, and Great Highland bagpipes. The band explains that these instruments accentuate the growling sound they favor. The 1991 R.E.M. hit "Losing My Religion" was driven by a few simple mandolin licks played by guitarist Peter Buck, who also played the mandolin in nearly a dozen other songs. The single peaked at No. 4 on the Billboard Hot 100 chart (#1 on the rock and alternative charts), Luther Dickinson of North Mississippi Allstars and The Black Crowes has made frequent use of the mandolin, most notably on the Black Crowes song "Locust Street." Armenian American rock group System of A Down makes extensive use of the mandolin on their 2005 double album Mezmerize/Hypnotize. Pop punk band Green Day has used a mandolin in several occasions, especially on their 2000 album, Warning. Boyd Tinsley, violin player of the Dave Matthews Band has been using an electric mandolin since 2005. Frontman Colin Meloy and guitarist Chris Funk of The Decemberists regularly employ the mandolin in the band's music. Nancy Wilson, rhythm guitarist of Heart, uses a mandolin in Heart's song "Dream of the Archer" from the album Little Queen, as well as in Heart's cover of Led Zeppelin's song "The Battle of Evermore." "Show Me Heaven" by Maria McKee, the theme song to the film Days of Thunder, prominently features a mandolin.

President Truman, symbolizing a broad-based desire for an Eisenhower candidacy for president, again in 1951 pressed him to run for the office as a Democrat. It was at this time that Eisenhower voiced his disagreements with the Democratic party and declared himself and his family to be Republicans. A "Draft Eisenhower" movement in the Republican Party persuaded him to declare his candidacy in the 1952 presidential election to counter the candidacy of non-interventionist Senator Robert A. Taft. The effort was a long struggle; Eisenhower had to be convinced that political circumstances had created a genuine duty for him to offer himself as a candidate, and that there was a mandate from the populace for him to be their President. Henry Cabot Lodge, who served as his campaign manager, and others succeeded in convincing him, and in June 1952 he resigned his command at NATO to campaign full-time. Eisenhower defeated Taft for the nomination, having won critical delegate votes from Texas. Eisenhower's campaign was noted for the simple but effective slogan, "I Like Ike". It was essential to his success that Eisenhower express opposition to Roosevelt's policy at Yalta and against Truman's policies in Korea and China—matters in which he had once participated. In defeating Taft for the nomination, it became necessary for Eisenhower to appease the right wing Old Guard of the Republican Party; his selection of Richard M. Nixon as the Vice-President on the ticket was designed in part for that purpose. Nixon also provided a strong anti-communist presence as well as some youth to counter Ike's more advanced age.

In 2006, Morgan Stanley purchased 20 acres (8.1 ha) directly north of the Showboat Atlantic City Hotel and Casino for a new $2 billion plus casino resort. Revel Entertainment Group was named as the project's developer for the Revel Casino. Revel was hindered with many problems, with the biggest setback to the company being in April 2010 when Morgan Stanley, the owner of 90% of Revel Entertainment Group, decided to discontinue funding for continued construction and put its stake in Revel up for sale. Early in 2010 the New Jersey state legislature passed a bill offering tax incentives to attract new investors and complete the job, but a poll by Fairleigh Dickinson University's PublicMind released in March 2010 showed that three of five voters (60%) opposed the legislation, and two of three of those who opposed it "strongly" opposed it. Ultimately, Governor Chris Christie offered Revel $261 million in state tax credits to assist the casino once it opened. As of March 2011[update], Revel had completed all of the exterior work and had continued work on the interior after finally receiving the funding necessary to complete construction. It had a soft opening in April 2012, and was fully open by May 2012. Ten months later, in February 2013, after serious losses and a write-down in the value of the resort from $2.4 billion to $450 million, Revel filed for Chapter 11 bankruptcy. It was restructured but still could not carry on and re-entered bankruptcy on June 19, 2014. It was put up for sale, however as no suitable bids were received the resort closed its doors on September 2, 2014.

The final major aspect of identity formation is self-esteem. Self-esteem is defined as one's thoughts and feelings about one's self-concept and identity. Most theories on self-esteem state that there is a grand desire, across all genders and ages, to maintain, protect and enhance their self-esteem. Contrary to popular belief, there is no empirical evidence for a significant drop in self-esteem over the course of adolescence. "Barometric self-esteem" fluctuates rapidly and can cause severe distress and anxiety, but baseline self-esteem remains highly stable across adolescence. The validity of global self-esteem scales has been questioned, and many suggest that more specific scales might reveal more about the adolescent experience. Girls are most likely to enjoy high self-esteem when engaged in supportive relationships with friends, the most important function of friendship to them is having someone who can provide social and moral support. When they fail to win friends' approval or couldn't find someone with whom to share common activities and common interests, in these cases, girls suffer from low self-esteem. In contrast, boys are more concerned with establishing and asserting their independence and defining their relation to authority. As such, they are more likely to derive high self-esteem from their ability to successfully influence their friends; on the other hand, the lack of romantic competence, for example, failure to win or maintain the affection of the opposite or same-sex (depending on sexual orientation), is the major contributor to low self-esteem in adolescent boys. Due to the fact that both men and women happen to have a low self-esteem after ending a romantic relationship, they are prone to other symptoms that is caused by this state. Depression and hopelessness are only two of the various symptoms and it is said that women are twice as likely to experience depression and men are three to four times more likely to commit suicide (Mearns, 1991; Ustun & Sartorius, 1995).

For its complete North American release, the Nintendo Entertainment System was progressively released over the ensuing years in four different bundles: the Deluxe Set, the Control Deck, the Action Set and the Power Set. The Deluxe Set, retailing at US$199.99 (equivalent to $475 in 2016), included R.O.B., a light gun called the NES Zapper, two controllers, and two Game Paks: Gyromite, and Duck Hunt. The Basic Set, retailing at US$89.99 with no game, and US$99.99 bundled with "Super Mario Bros." The Action Set, retailing in 1988 for US$149.99, came with the Control Deck, two game controllers, an NES Zapper, and a dual Game Pak containing both Super Mario Bros. and Duck Hunt. In 1989, the Power Set included the console, two game controllers, a NES Zapper, a Power Pad, and a triple Game Pak containing Super Mario Bros, Duck Hunt, and World Class Track Meet. In 1990, a Sports Set bundle was released, including the console, an NES Satellite infrared wireless multitap adapter, four game controllers, and a dual Game Pak containing Super Spike V'Ball and Nintendo World Cup. Two more bundle packages were later released using the original model NES console. The Challenge Set of 1992 included the console, two controllers, and a Super Mario Bros. 3 Game Pak for a retail price of US$89.99. The Basic Set, first released in 1987, was repackaged for a retail US$89.99. It included only the console and two controllers, and no longer was bundled with a cartridge. Instead, it contained a book called the Official Nintendo Player's Guide, which contained detailed information for every NES game made up to that point.

A period of division for the Liberals followed, with former Treasurer John Howard competing with former Foreign Minister Andrew Peacock for supremacy. The Australian economy was facing the early 1990s recession. Unemployment reached 11.4% in 1992. Under Dr John Hewson, in November 1991, the opposition launched the 650-page Fightback! policy document − a radical collection of "dry", economic liberal measures including the introduction of a Goods and Services Tax (GST), various changes to Medicare including the abolition of bulk billing for non-concession holders, the introduction of a nine-month limit on unemployment benefits, various changes to industrial relations including the abolition of awards, a $13 billion personal income tax cut directed at middle and upper income earners, $10 billion in government spending cuts, the abolition of state payroll taxes and the privatisation of a large number of government owned enterprises − representing the start of a very different future direction to the keynesian economic conservatism practiced by previous Liberal/National Coalition governments. The 15 percent GST was the centerpiece of the policy document. Through 1992, Labor Prime Minister Paul Keating mounted a campaign against the Fightback package, and particularly against the GST, which he described as an attack on the working class in that it shifted the tax burden from direct taxation of the wealthy to indirect taxation as a broad-based consumption tax. Pressure group activity and public opinion was relentless, which led Hewson to exempt food from the proposed GST − leading to questions surrounding the complexity of what food was and wasn't to be exempt from the GST. Hewson's difficulty in explaining this to the electorate was exemplified in the infamous birthday cake interview, considered by some as a turning point in the election campaign. Keating won a record fifth consecutive Labor term at the 1993 election. A number of the proposals were later adopted in to law in some form, to a small extent during the Keating Labor government, and to a larger extent during the Howard Liberal government (most famously the GST), while unemployment benefits and bulk billing were re-targeted for a time by the Abbott Liberal government.

Constantius, ordered Liberius into exile in 356 giving him, then, three days to comply. He was ordered into banishment to Beroea, in Thrace; Beroea (Thrace). He sent expensive presents, too, if he were to accept the Arian position but were refused. He sent him, indeed, five hundred pieces of gold "to bear his charges" but Liberius refused them, saying, he might bestow them on his flatters; as he did also a like present from the empress, bidding the messenger learn to believe in Christ, and not to persecute the Church of God. Attempts were made to leave the presents in The Church, but Liberius threw them out. Constantius hereupon sent for him under a strict guard to Milan, where, in a conference recorded by Theodoret, he boldly told Constantius that Athanasius had been acquitted at Sardica, and his enemies proved calumniators (see: "calumny") and impostors, and that it was unjust to condemn a person who could not be legally convicted of any crime. The emperor was reduced to silence on every article, but being the more out of patience, ordered him into banishment. Liberius went into exile. Constantius, after two years went to Rome to celebrate the twentieth year of his reign. The ladies joined in a petition to him that he would restore Liberius. He assented, upon condition that he should comply with the bishops, then, at court. He subscribed the condemnation of Athanasius, and a confession or creed which had been framed by the Arians at Sirmium. And he no sooner had recovered his see that he declared himself for the Creed of Niceae, as Theodoret testifies. (Theodoret, Hist. lib. ii. c. 17.). The Emperor knew what he wanted people to believe. So did the bishops at his court. Athanasius stuck by the orthodox creed. Constantius was an avowed Arian, became sole ruler in 350, at the death of his brother, Constans.

The Montana Territory was formed on April 26, 1864, when the U.S. passed the Organic Act. Schools started forming in the area before it was officially a territory as families started settling into the area. The first schools were subscription schools that typically held in the teacher's home. The first formal school on record was at Fort Owen in Bitterroot valley in 1862. The students were Indian children and the children of Fort Owen employees. The first school term started in early winter and only lasted until February 28. Classes were taught by Mr. Robinson. Another early subscription school was started by Thomas Dimsdale in Virginia City in 1863. In this school students were charged $1.75 per week. The Montana Territorial Legislative Assembly had its inaugural meeting in 1864. The first legislature authorized counties to levy taxes for schools, which set the foundations for public schooling. Madison County was the first to take advantage of the newly authorized taxes and it formed fhe first public school in Virginia City in 1886. The first school year was scheduled to begin in January 1866, but severe weather postponed its opening until March. The first school year ran through the summer and didn't end until August 17. One of the first teachers at the school was Sarah Raymond. She was a 25-year-old woman who had traveled to Virginia City via wagon train in 1865. To become a certified teacher, Raymond took a test in her home and paid a $6 fee in gold dust to obtain a teaching certificate. With the help of an assistant teacher, Mrs. Farley, Raymond was responsible for teaching 50 to 60 students each

On 20 June 1794, Burke received a vote of thanks from the Commons for his services in the Hastings Trial and he immediately resigned his seat, being replaced by his son Richard. A tragic blow fell upon Burke with the loss of Richard in August 1794, to whom he was tenderly attached, and in whom he saw signs of promise, which were not patent to others and which, in fact, appear to have been non-existent (though this view may have rather reflected the fact that Richard Burke had worked successfully in the early battle for Catholic emancipation). King George III, whose favour he had gained by his attitude on the French Revolution, wished to create him Earl of Beaconsfield, but the death of his son deprived the opportunity of such an honour and all its attractions, so the only award he would accept was a pension of £2,500. Even this modest reward was attacked by the Duke of Bedford and the Earl of Lauderdale, to whom Burke replied in his Letter to a Noble Lord (1796): "It cannot at this time be too often repeated; line upon line; precept upon precept; until it comes into the currency of a proverb, To innovate is not to reform". He argued that he was rewarded on merit, but the Duke of Bedford received his rewards from inheritance alone, his ancestor being the original pensioner: "Mine was from a mild and benevolent sovereign; his from Henry the Eighth". The nation almost immediately fell into civil war that involved various factions fighting one another; these factions were often distinguished by clan loyalties. More than 500,000 residents fled during this time because of persecution, increased poverty and better economic opportunities in the West or in other former Soviet republics. Emomali Rahmon came to power in 1992, defeating former prime minister Abdumalik Abdullajanov in a November presidential election with 58% of the vote. The elections took place shortly after the end of the war, and Tajikistan was in a state of complete devastation. The estimated dead numbered over 100,000. Around 1.2 million people were refugees inside and outside of the country. In 1997, a ceasefire was reached between Rahmon and opposition parties under the guidance of Gerd D. Merrem, Special Representative to the Secretary General, a result widely praised as a successful United Nations peace keeping initiative. The ceasefire guaranteed 30% of ministerial positions would go to the opposition. Elections were held in 1999, though they were criticized by opposition parties and foreign observers as unfair and Rahmon was re-elected with 98% of the vote. Elections in 2006 were again won by Rahmon (with 79% of the vote) and he began his third term in office. Several opposition parties boycotted the 2006 election and the Organization for Security and Cooperation in Europe (OSCE) criticized it, although observers from the Commonwealth of Independent States claimed the elections were legal and transparent. Rahmon's administration came under further criticism from the OSCE in October 2010 for its censorship and repression of the media. The OSCE claimed that the Tajik Government censored Tajik and foreign websites and instituted tax inspections on independent printing houses that led to the cessation of printing activities for a number of independent newspapers.

Several explanations have been offered for Yale’s representation in national elections since the end of the Vietnam War. Various sources note the spirit of campus activism that has existed at Yale since the 1960s, and the intellectual influence of Reverend William Sloane Coffin on many of the future candidates. Yale President Richard Levin attributes the run to Yale’s focus on creating "a laboratory for future leaders," an institutional priority that began during the tenure of Yale Presidents Alfred Whitney Griswold and Kingman Brewster. Richard H. Brodhead, former dean of Yale College and now president of Duke University, stated: "We do give very significant attention to orientation to the community in our admissions, and there is a very strong tradition of volunteerism at Yale." Yale historian Gaddis Smith notes "an ethos of organized activity" at Yale during the 20th century that led John Kerry to lead the Yale Political Union's Liberal Party, George Pataki the Conservative Party, and Joseph Lieberman to manage the Yale Daily News. Camille Paglia points to a history of networking and elitism: "It has to do with a web of friendships and affiliations built up in school." CNN suggests that George W. Bush benefited from preferential admissions policies for the "son and grandson of alumni", and for a "member of a politically influential family." New York Times correspondent Elisabeth Bumiller and The Atlantic Monthly correspondent James Fallows credit the culture of community and cooperation that exists between students, faculty, and administration, which downplays self-interest and reinforces commitment to others.

The last major building work took place during the reign of King George V when, in 1913, Sir Aston Webb redesigned Blore's 1850 East Front to resemble in part Giacomo Leoni's Lyme Park in Cheshire. This new, refaced principal façade (of Portland stone) was designed to be the backdrop to the Victoria Memorial, a large memorial statue of Queen Victoria, placed outside the main gates. George V, who had succeeded Edward VII in 1910, had a more serious personality than his father; greater emphasis was now placed on official entertaining and royal duties than on lavish parties. He arranged a series of command performances featuring jazz musicians such as the Original Dixieland Jazz Band (1919) – the first jazz performance for a head of state, Sidney Bechet, and Louis Armstrong (1932), which earned the palace a nomination in 2009 for a (Kind of) Blue Plaque by the Brecon Jazz Festival as one of the venues making the greatest contribution to jazz music in the United Kingdom. George V's wife Queen Mary was a connoisseur of the arts, and took a keen interest in the Royal Collection of furniture and art, both restoring and adding to it. Queen Mary also had many new fixtures and fittings installed, such as the pair of marble Empire-style chimneypieces by Benjamin Vulliamy, dating from 1810, which the Queen had installed in the ground floor Bow Room, the huge low room at the centre of the garden façade. Queen Mary was also responsible for the decoration of the Blue Drawing Room. This room, 69 feet (21 metres) long, previously known as the South Drawing Room, has a ceiling designed specially by Nash, coffered with huge gilt console brackets.

The departures of Núñez and van Gaal were hardly noticed by the fans when compared to that of Luís Figo, then club vice-captain. Figo had become a cult hero, and was considered by Catalans to be one of their own. However, Barcelona fans were distraught by Figo's decision to join arch-rivals Real Madrid, and, during subsequent visits to the Camp Nou, Figo was given an extremely hostile reception. Upon his first return, a piglet's head and a full bottle of whiskey were thrown at him from the crowd. The next three years saw the club in decline, and managers came and went. van Gaal was replaced by Llorenç Serra Ferrer who, despite an extensive investment in players in the summer of 2000, presided over a mediocre league campaign and a humiliating first-round Champions League exit, and was eventually dismissed late in the season. Long-serving coach Carles Rexach was appointed as his replacement, initially on a temporary basis, and managed to at least steer the club to the last Champions League spot on the final day of the season. Despite better form in La Liga and a good run to the semi-finals of the Champions League, Rexach was never viewed as a long-term solution and that summer Louis van Gaal returned to the club for a second spell as manager. What followed, despite another decent Champions League performance, was one of the worst La Liga campaigns in the club's history, with the team as low as 15th in February 2003. This led to van Gaal's resignation and replacement for the rest of the campaign by Radomir Antić, though a sixth-place finish was the best that he could manage. At the end of the season, Antić's short-term contract was not renewed, and club president Joan Gaspart resigned, his position having been made completely untenable by such a disastrous season on top of the club's overall decline in fortunes since he became president three years prior.

In the year of fifty-four, beneath the sky so wide,  
Writers, critics, linguists, set aside their pride.  
Serbs and Croats, Montenegrins, too,  
In Novi Sad they gathered, with a vision to pursue.  

Matica srpska, Matica hrvatska, hand in hand,  
Signed an agreement, for unity they planned.  
A single language shared, but with variants two,  
One from Zagreb, the other Belgrade, both equally true.  

Cyrillic, Latin, scripts were held the same,  
Ekavian, Ijekavian, pronunciations they did name.  
Serbo-Croatian, the official tongue to proclaim,  
Yet Serbian and Croatian, in hearts, remained.  

Together they toiled, on dictionaries they penned,  
A committee of minds, to language they did tend.  
In the sixties, in cities, the books they unveiled,  
Ijekavian in Zagreb, Ekavian in Novi Sad prevailed.  

But whispers of unitarianism soon did rise,  
Croatian linguists with a skeptical guise.  
Stjepan Babić spoke of alphabets on screens,  
Yet proof evaded where prestige convenes.  

The dictionary listed words side by side,  
Seen by some as respect, not unitarism applied.  
Critics of unitarism even penned those lines,  
Ignoring their origin from Croatian designs.  

Out of this debate, a declaration did come,  
In sixty-seven, a stand for the Croatian tongue.  
For forty-five years, the debate would endure,  
In twenty-twelve, Forum revived the allure.  

Through the lens of time, criticism and praise,  
The Novi Sad Agreement, in history stays.  
A journey of language, where voices intertwine,  
In the Balkans' story, a linguistic line.

The Bush administration, having firmly decided on a new foreign policy trajectory, shifted focus to Iraq with a narrative that emphasized the immediate necessity of deposing Saddam Hussein. This urgency was attributed to a range of allegations: Saddam's regime was accused of actively seeking nuclear materials and failing to adequately account for the biological and chemical arsenal it was previously documented to possess. These actions, or lack thereof, constituted a breach of existing United Nations sanctions. The Bush administration vigorously championed the existence of weapons of mass destruction (WMD) within Iraq, asserting this threat as a cornerstone of their drive for military intervention. Despite this persistent assertion, skepticism permeated the international community; influential nations such as China, France, Germany, and Russia expressed doubt regarding the immediacy of the Iraqi threat, subsequently thwarting attempts to secure a UN Security Council resolution that would sanction the use of force.

In a move to counter these international reservations, Iraq allowed UN weapons inspectors to enter in November 2002, authorizing them to investigate the veracity of the WMD claims. However, before the completion of their assessment, the Bush administration, resolved in its course of action, instructed the inspectors to withdraw, choosing to unilaterally initiate military action without UN endorsement. The United States, supported by a "coalition of the willing" comprising primarily British forces, along with smaller contingents from Australia and Poland, launched an invasion on March 20, 2003. This swift military campaign, overwhelming in its execution, dismantled the Iraqi government's structures and defeated its military forces within a mere three weeks.

Despite the rapid military success, the anticipated discovery of WMDs remained elusive. Investigators uncovered remnants of previous weapon programs and facilities, yet conclusive evidence—a definitive "smoking gun"—was never found. This absence soon became a focal point of controversy. Nonetheless, on May 1, President George W. Bush made a dramatic arrival aboard the USS Abraham Lincoln via a Lockheed S-3 Viking aircraft, delivering a speech beneath a banner proclaiming "Mission Accomplished," as he declared the cessation of "major combat operations" in Iraq. At this juncture, Bush enjoyed a robust approval rating of 66% according to a CNN–USA Today–Gallup poll, buoyed by public perception of swift military success.

An adolescent's environment plays a pivotal role in their identity development, influencing various dimensions of their psychological, social, and emotional growth. While a significant proportion of adolescent studies have historically concentrated on white, middle-class children, emerging research underscores the correlation between a privileged upbringing and more effective identity formation. The construction of an adolescent’s identity represents a critical juncture in their developmental trajectory, encompassing diverse aspects of self-conception and social awareness. Recent findings have illuminated demographic trends indicating that the transition to adulthood now extends over a more protracted period than was typical in the mid-20th century. Consequently, the concept of youth—a developmental stage bridging late adolescence and early adulthood—has gained increased significance within the broader life course framework. This temporal expansion has rendered various developmental factors more salient, necessitating a nuanced understanding of their interplay in identity formation.

Numerous variables contribute to the evolving social identity of adolescents, ranging from personal commitment and coping mechanisms to the pervasive influence of social media. Each of these dimensions is intricately shaped by the environment in which the adolescent is nurtured. Adolescents from more privileged backgrounds typically have access to a wider array of opportunities and are situated in contexts conducive to positive developmental outcomes. Conversely, adolescents from inner-city areas or neighborhoods characterized by high crime rates may encounter environments that pose significant risks to their developmental wellbeing. Adolescence, being a particularly sensitive phase of the developmental process, renders individuals especially susceptible to environmental influences, which can have profound implications for their future decision-making and life trajectories.

In comparison with other team sports, the National Football League (NFL) preseason is uniquely structured to balance both preparation and competitive integrity. Each of the 32 NFL teams participates in precisely four preseason exhibition games annually, evenly split between home and away venues, with the exception of two teams that partake in an additional fifth game known as the Pro Football Hall of Fame Game. These exhibition encounters predominantly occur in August, serving a crucial role in allowing coaches to evaluate player performance and make informed decisions to trim the roster from the offseason allowance of 90 players to a streamlined regular-season roster of 53. Although the scheduling for these preseason matches is not as formulaically stringent as it is for the regular season, it is bounded by numerous restrictions and entrenched traditions that influence opponent selection and dictate permissible days and times for these contests. Notably, the NFL prohibits split-squad games—a concept prevalent in sports such as baseball and hockey where a team divides to play two concurrent games—maintaining a focus on team cohesion and player assessment. 

Furthermore, the NFL has historically used exhibition games as a strategic vehicle to globalize its brand, staging games in diverse international locales including Europe, Japan, Canada, Australia, and Mexico. An attempt to expand to China was contemplated but ultimately abandoned due to financial and logistical hurdles. Critically, the NFL maintains a policy of not engaging with non-league opponents, a practice that has been in place since the last interleague game in 1972 and the concluding match against a team other than an NFL member, which involved the all-NFL rookie College All-Stars in 1976. Despite their intended purpose, exhibition games have faced criticism from fans, primarily due to the pricing structure, which compels season-ticket holders to pay regular-season prices for the less popular exhibition matches. In the intricate world of professional wrestling, the role of a referee is as crucial as it is nuanced, often requiring a delicate balance of authority and discretion. While a strict adherence to the rules is expected, the reality is that not every infraction results in an immediate halt to the match. Referees wield the power of judgement, allowing them to assess the situation and determine whether the match should continue or be stopped. This discretionary power means that only the most flagrant violations such as low blows, the use of foreign objects, interference from outside parties, or the unthinkable act of attacking the referee will prompt an automatic disqualification without the need for repeated offenses.

In the theatrical realm of WWE, the criteria for a disqualification are particular: the referee must witness the infraction firsthand, as reliance on video evidence is typically insufficient. The referee’s verdict is generally final, lending an air of authority and immediacy to their decisions. However, in the world of wrestling, surprises are always around the corner, and the phenomenon known as "Dusty finishes" can lead to moments where a referee's decision is contested and overturned, adding layers of drama and unpredictability to the storyline.

An intriguing aspect of wrestling is the frequent occurrence of "ref bumps," where referees find themselves inadvertently knocked unconscious during the heat of battle. This momentary absence of authority allows wrestlers a period of rule-breaking freedom, a dramatic device often used to escalate tension and excitement. During this time, wrestlers can, and often do, flout the rules, taking advantage of the referee's temporary incapacity. This construction effectively connected the building to the tower, thereby forming a prominent main entrance. The project of constructing the main chapel was initiated in 1674 by Archbishop Luis Alfonso de los Cameros, with the interiors adorned in the Baroque style characteristic of that era, utilizing marbles and bronzes for decoration. As the 18th century commenced, the façade of the main entrance was constructed by the German architect Conrad Rudolphus, adding a distinctive feature to the structure. The cathedral possesses two additional doors leading into the transept. One of these, known as the Door of the Apostles, is a fine example of pure pointed Gothic architecture dating back to the 14th century, while the other is referred to as the Door of the Paláu. Architectural alterations at the rear of the cathedral have somewhat diminished its original height. The restoration efforts in the 18th century resulted in the rounding of the pointed arches, the covering of Gothic columns with Corinthian pillars, and a general redecoration of the walls. The dome, lacking a lantern, features a plain ceiling that is illuminated by two large side windows. The interior houses eight chapels, with four located on each side, in addition to those opening into the choir, the transept, and the sanctuary. The intense scrutiny and relentless media fascination with the British royal family during the 1980s ushered in an era of sensational journalism, which was marked by a proliferation of stories that blurred the lines between fact and fiction. This era of tabloid sensationalism reached its zenith under the editorial direction of figures like Kelvin MacKenzie of The Sun, who famously urged his reporters to generate eye-catching headlines about the royals without regard for their veracity. His cavalier attitude toward factual accuracy epitomized a broader trend within the media, as noted by Donald Trelford of The Observer, who lamented the degradation of journalistic standards and the erosion of the boundary between reality and fabrication in royal coverage. This period saw various unsubstantiated or exaggerated claims gain traction, fueled by a voracious public appetite for royal intrigue. A particularly notable instance was the alleged tension between Queen Elizabeth II and Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher, driven by purported royal discontent with Thatcher's economic and social policies, as reported by The Sunday Times. The narrative, reportedly fueled by comments from royal aide Michael Shea and Commonwealth Secretary-General Shridath Ramphal, was later disputed and dismissed as journalistic embellishment. Despite claims of discord, the personal relationship between the Queen and Thatcher was characterized by mutual respect, as evidenced by the Queen bestowing prestigious honors upon Thatcher post-premiership. Furthermore, assertions of the Queen's political inclinations were speculative and unfounded, with John Campbell, Thatcher's biographer, labeling such reports as mischievous fabrications. In retrospect, these episodes underscore the media's role in shaping public perceptions through a blend of fact and fiction, while also highlighting the complexities of the relationship between the monarchy, the government, and the media during a transformative period in British history. The palace, a monumental structure, spans dimensions of 108 meters (354 feet) by 120 meters (390 feet) and reaches a height of 24 meters (79 feet). It boasts over 77,000 square meters (830,000 square feet) of floorspace, which, while expansive, is less than that of notable landmarks such as the Royal Palace of Madrid, the Papal Palace in Rome, the Louvre in Paris, the Hofburg Palace in Vienna, and the Forbidden City in Beijing. The building encompasses a total of 775 rooms, comprising 19 state rooms, 52 principal bedrooms, 188 staff bedrooms, 92 offices, and 78 bathrooms. The principal rooms are located on the piano nobile, positioned behind the west-facing garden façade at the rear of the palace. Within this opulent suite of state rooms, the Music Room stands at the center, its prominent bow feature defining the façade. Adjacent to the Music Room are the Blue and White Drawing Rooms. At the heart of the suite, the Picture Gallery serves as a corridor connecting the state rooms. This gallery, measuring 55 yards (50 meters) in length, is top-lit and adorned with numerous artworks, including masterpieces by Rembrandt, van Dyck, Rubens, and Vermeer. Additional rooms branching from the Picture Gallery include the Throne Room and the Green Drawing Room. The Green Drawing Room acts as a grand anteroom to the Throne Room and forms part of the ceremonial pathway to the throne, originating from the Guard Room at the apex of the Grand Staircase. To extend and consolidate the dynasty's dominion in the vast and untamed expanses of Central Asia, the illustrious Kangxi Emperor, a man of vision and resolve, personally took charge of a series of meticulously orchestrated military campaigns against the formidable Dzungars in the rugged terrains of Outer Mongolia. With strategic brilliance and unwavering determination, the Kangxi Emperor managed to thwart and expel the marauding forces of Galdan, securing these contested regions, which were then seamlessly incorporated into the burgeoning empire. The saga reached its climax when Galdan met his demise during the fierce Dzungar–Qing War, a pivotal moment that reshaped the balance of power in the region.

In the year 1683, a momentous event unfolded as the resolute Qing forces witnessed the surrender of Taiwan from the hands of Zheng Keshuang, the grandson of the legendary Koxinga. Koxinga, a formidable figure in his own right, had wrested control of Taiwan from the Dutch colonists, using it as a strategic base to challenge Qing authority. In a gesture that reflected the nuanced diplomacy of the era, Zheng Keshuang was bestowed with the noble title "Duke Haicheng" (海澄公) and was ceremoniously inducted into the Han Chinese Plain Red Banner of the esteemed Eight Banners upon his relocation to the imperial heart of Beijing.

Accompanying Koxinga to Taiwan in the years 1661-1662 were several Ming princes, including the distinguished Prince of Ningjing Zhu Shugui and Prince Zhu Honghuan (朱弘桓), the son of Zhu Yihai. These princes found refuge in the Kingdom of Tungning, a bastion of resistance against Qing rule. After Taiwan's fall in 1683, the Qing Dynasty, in a display of magnanimity, spared the lives of the 17 remaining Ming princes living on the island, exiling them to mainland China where they lived out their days

From the 1970s onward, Stuart Hall's pioneering work, along with that of his colleagues Paul Willis, Dick Hebdige, Tony Jefferson, and Angela McRobbie, created an international intellectual movement that profoundly shaped the landscape of academic thought and discourse. As the field of cultural studies evolved, it began to intricately weave together diverse academic disciplines such as political economy, communication, sociology, social theory, literary theory, media theory, film and video studies, cultural anthropology, philosophy, as well as museum studies and art history, to thoroughly examine cultural phenomena or texts. Within this rich tapestry of interdisciplinary study, researchers often delve deeply into exploring how specific phenomena are intertwined with complex matters of ideology, nationality, ethnicity, social class, and gender.

Cultural studies is particularly invested in unraveling the intricate web of meanings and practices that make up everyday life. These practices include the myriad ways individuals engage in specific activities, such as watching television or dining out, within a given cultural context. In this sphere of study, the emphasis is on the meanings and uses that people attribute to various objects and practices, often revealing that culture encompasses those meanings and practices that exist independently of rational justification. For instance, watching television to gain a public perspective on a historical event may not be considered culture unless the choice of television as a medium itself is culturally informed. However, schoolchildren gathering to watch television with their peers after school to "fit in" certainly qualifies as culture, as it involves a practice devoid of a logical reason for participation.

Libya's economy experienced a significant shift toward privatization, marking a departure from the socialist policies of nationalized industries advocated in The Green Book. Despite this move away from traditional socialism, government officials maintained that they were establishing a form of "people's socialism" rather than embracing outright capitalism. Gaddafi, the nation's leader, expressed support for these economic reforms by advocating for extensive privatization during a speech delivered in March 2003. Following this, Libya's oil industry saw substantial privatization, with much of it being sold to private corporations. By 2004, Libya attracted $40 billion in direct foreign investment, representing a sixfold increase from the previous year. However, these changes were met with resistance from certain segments of the Libyan population, leading to public demonstrations. In March 2006, revolutionary hard-liners assumed control of the General People's Congress (GPC) cabinet. Although they moderated the pace of reforms, they did not entirely reverse them. By 2010, plans were underway to privatize half of the Libyan economy over the next decade. Despite these economic transformations, there was no corresponding political liberalization, with Gaddafi maintaining dominant authority. Nonetheless, in March 2010, the government took steps to decentralize power by transferring more responsibilities to municipal councils. During this period, the governance of Libya saw an influx of reform-minded technocrats, notably Gaddafi's son, Saif al-Islam Gaddafi. Recognized for his criticism of Libya's human rights practices, Saif was instrumental in proposing the drafting of a new constitution, though it was ultimately not adopted. Mammalian hair, known as pelage fair,  
Dances with colors, a vibrant affair.  
Shades that shift and sway, from dusk to dawn,  
Across populations, they are drawn.  

In nature's canvas, hues do twirl,  
Light and dark in a spiral whirl.  
From age to age, from young to old,  
The stories of their colors told.  

Selective whispers in the wild's embrace,  
Guide these colors in their place.  
Ecology's hand, a painter's touch,  
In camouflage, they blend so much.  

A cloak of mystery, a shield of might,  
Hiding from predators, there lies their fight.  
Yet colors speak in whispers and cries,  
In mating dances, beneath the skies.  

Coat of many colors, a silent call,  
For mates to hear, for kin to heed all.  
In hues so bright or soft and mild,  
Messages sent from mother to child.  

Through genes and traits, the stories flow,  
In pigmentation's ebb and glow.  
Mapping the codes, a quest begun,  
To learn the secrets under the sun.  

While much remains a mystery,  
In genes and pigments' history.  
A symphony of color, wide and vast,  
In nature's arms, forever cast.

In the vibrant milieu of the mid-18th century, the French Enlightenment thrived as an era of profound intellectual exploration and revolutionary thought. It was during this transformative period that the term "humanism" began to evolve, gaining ideological traction among the era's thinkers and writers. The year 1765 marked a significant moment when the author of an anonymous article, published in a prominent French Enlightenment periodical, articulated a vision of "The general love of humanity." This concept was heralded as a virtue without a name, and the author boldly proposed the term "humanism" to capture the essence of this beautiful and necessary ideal, arguing that the time had come to formalize such a noble concept in the lexicon of human virtues.

As the Enlightenment unfolded, particularly in the latter part of the 18th and early 19th centuries, a wave of grassroots movements emerged, motivated by the ideals of philanthropy and benevolence. These societies were committed to the betterment of humanity and the dissemination of knowledge, though they varied in their adherence to religious doctrines, with some aligning with Christian values and others not. This burgeoning enthusiasm for human improvement and intellectual advancement gained momentum following the seismic events of the French Revolution.

However, the post-revolutionary landscape was marked by a fierce ideological clash. Enlightenment philosophes, such as Rousseau, championed the belief that human virtue and progress could be achieved through reason alone, independent of traditional religious institutions. This radical idea, however, faced vehement opposition from influential religious and political conservatives, including figures like Edmund Burke and Joseph de Maistre. They viewed the Enlightenment's emphasis on reason over faith as a perilous form of idolatry, a deification of humanity that threatened to destabilize the religious and moral order.

Consequently, the term "humanism" began to acquire a negative connotation, especially when invoked by critics of the Enlightenment. The Oxford English Dictionary notes that by 1812, an English clergyman used "humanism" to describe the views of Unitarians and Deists, who emphasized Christ's "mere humanity" rather than his divine nature. In political systems where three or more parties are present, it is uncommon for a single party to independently secure a governing majority. Consequently, parties often collaborate to form coalition governments, a trend that has been notably prominent in the political landscape of the Republic of Ireland since the 1980s. This pattern is consistently observed in Germany, where coalition governments are the norm at both national and state levels, as well as in most communal constituencies. Similarly, the political scene in the Republic of Iceland has witnessed a perpetual reliance on coalition governments since its formation, frequently involving the Independence Party partnering with another party, often the Social Democratic Alliance. The situation in the Republic of Ireland mirrors this, with no party gaining sole power since 1989, leading to the establishment of various coalition governments typically led by either Fianna Fáil or Fine Gael. Coalition governments are often argued to facilitate political change more effectively than systems dominated by a single or two primary parties. In two-party systems, internal disagreements on policy goals or foundational principles can result in slow policy adaptation, a scenario currently evident in the United States with the power evenly divided between Democrats and Republicans. Despite this, coalition governments are not without challenges and may struggle for extended periods to implement policy changes, sometimes failing altogether, as seen in post-World War II France and Italy. In contrast, when one party in a two-party system gains control over all branches of government, policy changes can occur rapidly and significantly. This was demonstrated by Democrats such as Woodrow Wilson, Franklin Roosevelt, and Lyndon Johnson, as well as Republicans like Abraham Lincoln and Ronald Reagan. Emotions form a crucial substrate for social interactions and relationships, intertwining intricately with basic physiological processes, particularly the stress systems. These emotional drivers are vital due to their connection with the anti-stress complex, specifically the oxytocin-attachment system, which is fundamental in the formation of bonds. The role of emotions in fostering social ties suggests a deeper biological underpinning, as emotional phenotypes and temperaments critically influence social connectivity and fitness within complex social structures, as posited by Kurt Kortschal in 2013. This biological and emotional interplay extends beyond humans, resonating across various species and taxa, highlighting the pervasive influence of genetic factors and their perpetual transmission across generations. The genetic information imprinted in DNA sequences serves as a foundational blueprint, dictating the assembly of proteins that constitute our cellular framework. As zygotes assimilate genetic data from parental germ cells, they inherit traits that have historically facilitated the survival and reproductive success of their ancestors, alongside potentially advantageous new traits. Remarkably, despite the evolutionary divergence that separated the lineages of modern humans and chimpanzees approximately five million years ago, a mere 1.2% of genetic material exhibits modification. This minuscule genetic variance encapsulates profound distinctions, encompassing not only physiological attributes but also behavioral complexities. Scholars examining animal behavior primarily encounter intraspecific instances of genetic influence on behavioral phenotypes. For instance, in voles (Microtus spp.), minute genetic variations in a vasopressin receptor gene correlate with significant interspecies differences in social organization and mating systems, as elucidated by Hammock & Young in 2005. Similarly, the FOXP2 gene, associated with neural mechanisms governing speech and language, exemplifies the impact of slight genetic mutations—altered only marginally from its chimpanzee counterpart—and has been present in its current form in humans for approximately 200,000 years, as noted by Enard et al. in 2002. The implications of identity and its multifaceted nature ripple across the vast expanse of research traditions, each employing the lens of identity to scrutinize a myriad of phenomena, albeit with the precision of a prism casting myriad colors upon the canvas of human understanding. An intriguing facet of this exploration is the role of identity and its construction within occupational realms, where the intricacies of self-perception are woven into the very fabric of professional existence. This endeavor becomes increasingly arduous when one considers the realm of stigmatized vocations, or what sociologists might term "dirty work," a concept initially illuminated by Hughes in 1951.

The intellectual musings of Tracy and Trethewey (2005) shed light on the intricate dance individuals perform as they gravitate toward or retreat from certain occupations, influenced by the degree to which these roles affirm their aspirational image of an "organizational self" (Tracy & Trethewey, 2005, p. 169). Within this spectrum of occupational identities, some roles are adorned with societal approbation, while others bear the weight of stigma. Tracy's analysis poignantly highlights the plight of correctional officers endeavoring to shed the ignominious label of "glorified maids," as they navigate the treacherous waters of self-justification and value assignment in their vocational choices.

The pursuit of workplace satisfaction and an enhanced quality of life hinges on this delicate balance, as elucidated in Tracy and Scott's discourse (2006, p. 33). Those ensnared within the confines of such vocations must embark upon a journey of identity crafting, forging a self-conception that aligns with their personal values and societal perceptions. In their 2003 paper "Human Genetic Diversity and the Nonexistence of Biological Races," Jeffrey Long and Rick Kittles present an in-depth critique of the use of FST, a measure of genetic variance, in the context of human populations. They argue that the widely cited statistic suggesting that 85% of human genetic diversity is found within all human populations is misleading. This figure implies a simplistic view where every human group independently holds a vast reservoir of genetic variety. However, Long and Kittles contend that this perspective fails to accurately depict the complex tapestry of human population history. It overlooks the fact that human groups are not isolated entities but rather intricately connected through evolutionary lineages. Some groups serve as ancestral or parental to others, forming what are known as paraphyletic groups in relation to their descendant populations. 

Illustrating this concept, they point to the recent African origin theory, which postulates that the human population within Africa is paraphyletic to all other human groups globally. This African population stands as the ancestral source from which all non-African populations trace their roots. Importantly, Long and Kittles emphasize that the migration out of Africa was not a sweeping transfer of genetic diversity but rather a bottleneck event. During this migration, only a small, non-representative sample of the genetic diversity in Africa was carried forth by the emigrating groups. Consequently, non-African populations share closer genetic ties with certain African groups—likely those from East Africa—than with others. This migration bottleneck led to a gradual dilution of genetic diversity as populations settled further from their African origins. Each subsequent founding event marked a new genetic subset, highlighting the continuum of connection rather than independence among human groups.

Long and Kittles argue that, contrary to the 85% statistic, the distribution of genetic diversity is far more nuanced. They assert that nearly the entirety of human genetic diversity can be found within a single African population, while a population derived from New Guinea

The book experienced a prolific journey of translation during Darwin's lifetime, yet this process was fraught with challenges that underscored the complexities inherent in translating scientific concepts and metaphors. Translators often grappled with not just linguistic hurdles but also the temptation to inject their personal biases and agendas into the text. Darwin, attempting to navigate these turbulent waters, strategically distributed presentation copies in France and Germany, seeking capable individuals who could faithfully convey his ideas. However, the onus was on the translators to secure publishing arrangements locally. Among those he initially welcomed was Heinrich Georg Bronn, a respected figure in the fields of naturalism and geology. Unfortunately, Bronn's German translation in 1860 deviated from Darwin's intentions, as it infused Bronn's personal interpretations and contentious themes that Darwin had purposefully excluded. Notably, Bronn altered "favoured races" to "perfected races" and included essays on the origin of life and a concluding chapter on religious implications, reflecting his alignment with Naturphilosophie.

Following Bronn's death in 1862, a more accurate translation emerged through Julius Victor Carus in 1867, with whom Darwin maintained close correspondence. In contrast, Darwin's efforts to secure a reliable French translation faced significant setbacks. The translation by Clémence Royer in 1862, for instance, was accompanied by an introduction that framed Darwin's ideas as an alternative to religious revelation and included notions reminiscent of social Darwinism and eugenics. Moreover, her edition was laden with explanatory notes that often contradicted Darwin's own expressions of doubt. Despite his correspondence with Royer, subsequent editions in 1866 and 1870 remained contentious, as Darwin struggled to have her remove these annotations, leaving him dissatisfied until Edmond Barbier's translation in 1876.

Hegel's philosophy is a profound exploration of German idealism, particularly focusing on preserving the truths he perceives in it, especially those articulated by Kant. Kant emphasized that ethical reason possesses the capability to transcend finite inclinations, a notion Hegel wholeheartedly embraces. For Hegel, the very act of knowing an "object"—which can be anything external, from a physical entity to another human being—necessitates a fundamental identity between thought and being. This identity is encapsulated in his concept of "subject-object identity," where both subject (the observer, a human mind) and object (the observed entity) are unified in their essence through Spirit. Spirit, in Hegel's framework, is a non-supernatural reinterpretation of God, serving as the inner conceptual reality that links both subject and object, rendering them identical in essence.

However, in this journey toward understanding, the subject initially misconstrues every object it encounters as something alien, external, and separate from itself. Hegel illustrates this misunderstanding by pointing out that the object appears to the subject as alien, hence the subject fails to see its own reflection in what it observes. This misapprehension persists until Spirit achieves its "self-realization," a pivotal moment where Spirit evolves into Absolute Spirit. It is at this juncture that the subject recognizes every object as an extension of itself, realizing that both entities are manifestations of Spirit.

Self-realization is a significant transformative process, where the Spirit's nonsupernatural Mind, embodied in the collective consciousness of humanity, reaches a profound understanding. This revelation is marked by the recognition that every object is a reflection of the subject itself, and in this realization, Spirit attains the status of Absolute Spirit. In the annals of ancient history, there is a tale of a people who twice tasted the sweet nectar of political autonomy. The Israelites, those storied descendants of Abraham, first reveled in self-governance during the era of the Biblical judges, a time when the land was quilted with tribes, each guided by their chosen leaders. This tapestry of tribal independence unfolded into the grand narrative of the United Monarchy, a kingdom of lore and legend, united under the iconic figures of Saul, David, and Solomon. Yet, like all great epics, this chapter was not without its discord. After the dissolution of the United Monarchy, the once united land fragmented into the separate entities of Israel and Judah.

From the southern kingdom of Judah arose a new term, a new identity: "Jew." This name, an etymological descendant of the Roman "Judean," came to signify those who hailed from Judah, marking a poignant shift in identity from the broader "Israelites" to the more localized "Jews." This transformation in nomenclature, absent in the Torah, is vividly articulated in the Book of Esther, a post-exilic narrative found within the Ketuvim, the third segment of the Jewish Tanakh. Here, in the 4th century BCE, the identity of a people was codified for posterity.

The tale then takes a somber turn in 587 BCE, when Nebuchadnezzar II, sovereign of the Neo-Babylonian Empire, cast his shadow upon Jerusalem. Under his command, the First Temple was reduced to memory, and the elites of Judah were led away into exile. In September 2012, during the excitement of the Tokyo Game Show, Sony made a significant announcement that stirred the gaming world: a new, slimmer PlayStation 3 redesign, known as the CECH-4000, was slated for release in late 2012. This eagerly anticipated model promised enhanced storage options, available in two configurations—a 250 GB and a 500 GB hard drive—to cater to different user needs for game storage and multimedia entertainment. Sony unveiled three variants of this Super Slim design, each tailored to specific markets and preferences. The first came equipped with a substantial 500 GB hard drive, perfect for avid gamers with extensive digital libraries. The second variant, featuring a 250 GB hard drive, had limited availability as it was not released in PAL regions, making it a rare find in certain parts of the world. Meanwhile, a third version offered a budget-friendly alternative with 12 GB of flash storage, exclusively available in PAL regions, which users could upgrade with an official standalone 250 GB hard drive if they sought additional space. Complementing this sleek redesign was a vertical stand, adding a touch of elegance and practicality to the console's presentation. 

In the United Kingdom, the 500 GB model made its debut on September 28, 2012, with the 12 GB variant following on October 12, 2012, targeting different consumer segments. Across the Atlantic, the United States saw the PS3 Super Slim introduced as part of enticing bundles. The 250 GB model arrived bundled with the Game of the Year edition of Uncharted 3: Drake's Deception on September 25, 2012, drawing in fans of the action-adventure series. Meanwhile, the 500 GB version hit the shelves bundled with Assassin's Creed III on October 30, 2012, appealing to history buffs and action enthusiasts alike. Japan welcomed the black-colored Super Slim model on October 4, 2012, followed by the elegant white-colored variant on November 22, 2012, offering a choice between classic and contemporary aesthetics. In 1919, following the Treaty of Versailles, the city of Strasbourg was restituted to France in line with U.S. President Woodrow Wilson's "Fourteen Points," notably without holding a referendum. The official date of this territorial reassignment was retroactively fixed on Armistice Day. There remains a degree of skepticism as to whether a referendum in Strasbourg would have favored France, given that political parties advocating for either an autonomous Alsace or its connection to France garnered only a minor share of the vote in both the final Reichstag elections and local elections. Despite this, the pro-French Alsatian autonomists had gained significant support in the rural sections of the region and other towns since the annexation by Germany in 1871. The movement gained momentum with the inaugural Reichstag election, where those elected were known as "les députés protestataires." These deputies, until the fall of Chancellor Bismarck in 1890, were the sole representatives from Alsace in the German parliament who persistently demanded the return of the territories to French sovereignty. In the last Reichstag election in Strasbourg and its surrounding areas, the Social Democrats emerged as the dominant force. This outcome can be attributed to Strasbourg being the administrative capital of the region, with a significant population of Germans appointed by the Berlin central government, and its thriving economy, which drew many Germans to the area. This disparity in voting patterns between the rural areas and Strasbourg itself highlights the complex political landscape of the region at the time. Zhejiang Province, located on the east coast of China, has developed a robust economic structure characterized by its primary manufacturing sectors: electromechanical industries, textiles, chemical industries, food processing, and construction materials. In recent years, Zhejiang has implemented a distinctive economic strategy known as the "Zhejiang model." This model emphasizes fostering entrepreneurship, supporting the proliferation of small businesses that can quickly adapt to market changes, making significant public investments in infrastructure, and focusing on the mass production of affordable goods for both domestic and international markets. Consequently, Zhejiang has emerged as one of China's wealthiest provinces, and the innovative "Zhejiang spirit" has gained a legendary reputation across the country. Despite these achievements, some economists express concerns regarding the long-term sustainability of this model. Critics argue that the approach may be inefficient, as it strains raw materials and public utilities, and could potentially lead to stagnation, given the difficulty small enterprises face in transitioning to higher-value, technologically advanced industries. The province's economic center is gradually shifting from North Zhejiang, traditionally anchored by Hangzhou, towards the southeastern region, particularly around Wenzhou and Taizhou. In terms of economic performance, the per capita disposable income for urban residents in Zhejiang was 24,611 yuan (approximately US$3,603) in 2009, reflecting an annual real growth rate of 8.3%. During the early years of its operations, MCA expanded its influence in the videodisc market by manufacturing discs not only for its own titles but also for other major companies such as Paramount, Disney, and Warner Bros. This collaboration, however, was marked by a distinct ownership signifier; several of these companies ensured their brand names appeared on the disc jackets to clearly communicate that the films themselves were not owned by MCA. This nuanced branding underscores a competitive landscape where intellectual property and brand prestige were critically important. 

With the closure of Discovision Associates in early 1982, Universal Studio's videodisc software division, known as MCA Videodisc until 1984, took up the mantle of reissuing numerous titles previously under the DiscoVision label. However, this period was not without controversy or compromise. Many reissued titles, such as the iconic "Battlestar Galactica" and the blockbuster "Jaws," suffered from what can only be described as an artistic diminution through time compression. A particularly egregious example can be seen in the CLV re-issue of "Jaws," where cost-cutting measures led to the substitution of the original soundtrack's incidental music – a critical element of film narrative – with cheaper alternatives, due to prohibitive licensing costs. This decision left film purists longing for authenticity until the THX LaserDisc box set reinstated the original compositions in 1995.

Further complicating MCA's legacy is the handling of the Universal/Columbia co-production "The Electric Horseman." Despite being released in both CAV and CLV formats by MCA DiscoVision, this film remains unavailable in any other home video format that retains its original musical score. Subsequent

In southeast Europe, agrarian societies emerged during the 7th millennium BC, marking a significant shift from hunter-gatherer communities to settled agricultural practices. One of the earliest sites evidencing this transition is located in Vashtëmi, southeastern Albania, dating back to approximately 6,500 BC. This site provides critical insights into the nascent stages of farming in Europe. Concurrently, anthropomorphic figurines, indicative of early human artistry and cultural expression, began to appear in the Balkans around 6000 BC, and by circa 5800 BC, similar artifacts were found in Central Europe, at sites such as La Hoguette. This period saw the development of early cultural complexes, notably the Sesklo culture in Thessaly, which subsequently influenced the broader Balkan region, giving rise to the Starčevo-Körös (Cris), Linearbandkeramik, and Vinča cultures. These cultures played pivotal roles in the diffusion of Neolithic traditions, facilitating their spread westward and northward, ultimately reaching northwestern Europe by approximately 4500 BC. 

The Vinča culture is particularly noteworthy for its potential contribution to the development of writing systems, as evidenced by the Vinča signs. Although these signs are believed by archaeologist Shan Winn to be more likely pictograms and ideograms than a fully developed writing system, they nonetheless represent a significant step in the evolution of symbolic communication. Meanwhile, the Cucuteni-Trypillian culture established vast settlements in regions corresponding to modern-day Romania, Moldova, and Ukraine, flourishing from 5300 to 2300 BC. 

Further south, on the Mediterranean island of Gozo, part of the Maltese archipelago, the Ġgantija temple complex stands as a testament to the architectural ingenuity of Neolithic peoples, with its earliest structures dating back to circa 3600 BC. The nearby Mnajdra temple, along with the subterranean Hypogeum of Ħal-Saflieni in Paola, Malta—excavated around 2500 BC—demonstrates a remarkable degree of artistry and craftsmanship in stone sculpture, unique to the Maltese islands during prehistory. The Hypogeum, initially conceived as a sanctuary, later became a necropolis and remains the only prehistoric underground temple known worldwide.

For Karl Popper, the concept of knowledge transcended the mere subjective interpretations or experiences of individuals; it held an objective reality and truthfulness that could exist independently of any one person's consciousness. This notion was articulated in his work, "Objective Knowledge: An Evolutionary Approach" in 1972, wherein he delineated his theory of the three worlds. World One encompassed the tangible physical universe, the realm of objects and states that we can see, touch, and measure. World Two represented the internal domain of thoughts, emotions, and mental impressions, a sphere shaped by subjective experiences. However, it was World Three that captured Popper's revolutionary idea: the collective repository of human knowledge, an entity constructed over time through the creative and intellectual efforts of countless individuals. This world was populated by books, scientific theories, artworks, and musical compositions—each a testament to the human spirit's capacity to mold ideas into reality. World Three did not merely echo the mental fabric of World Two; it possessed an autonomous existence, evolving through interactions that spanned generations.

Popper posited that just as an animal creates a trail through repeated traversals, individual humans, through their intellectual endeavors, contribute to the ever-growing library of World Three. This repository, once formed, exerted a profound influence on the individual minds (World Two), often outweighing the sensory experiences and interactions with the physical realm (World One). In essence, the knowledge within an individual's mind was shaped as much by the cumulative heritage of humanity's intellectual pursuits as it was by direct encounters with the world. Strict separation of powers did not operate in the United Kingdom, the political structure of which served in most instances as a model for the government created by the U.S. Constitution. This divergence from strict separation lay in the UK's Westminster system, characterized by parliamentary sovereignty and responsible government. Within this framework, Parliament, which comprises the Sovereign (King-in-Parliament), the House of Lords, and the House of Commons, held the position as the supreme legislative authority, exercising ultimate lawmaking power. The executive branch operated in the name of the King, known as "His Majesty's Government," and similarly, the judiciary functioned under the monarch's authority. Notably, the King's Ministers were typically members of either the House of Commons or the House of Lords, underscoring the interconnectedness of the legislative and executive branches. Moreover, the Government's continuance required the support of a majority in the House of Commons, further illustrating the lack of stringent separation. A salient example of this overlap was the role of the Lord Chancellor, who simultaneously served as the sole judge in the Court of Chancery and as the presiding officer in the House of Lords, epitomizing the blending of judicial and legislative responsibilities. Consequently, it becomes evident that the three branches of British government frequently breached the strict principle of separation of powers, despite numerous instances of disagreement among different government branches. This blurred delineation was mirrored in some U.S. states during the 18th century, where a similar laxity in the separation of powers was observed. For instance, in New Jersey, the Governor concurrently held positions as a member of the state's highest court and as the presiding officer of one house of the New Jersey Legislature. Although Ottoman madaris had a number of different branches of study, such as calligraphic sciences, oral sciences, and intellectual sciences, they primarily served the function of an Islamic centre for spiritual learning, a sacred haven where the pursuit of knowledge was inherently intertwined with the quest for divine understanding. The goal of all knowledge, especially the spiritual sciences, was seen as the exalted knowledge of God. Religion was the axis upon which the significance and hierarchy of each science revolved; it was the lens through which the value and purpose of learning were assessed. As İnalcık insightfully notes, sciences that were perceived to aid religion were deemed virtuous, while others, like astrology, were viewed with disdain. Yet, even ostensibly secular disciplines such as mathematics or logic were not exempt from this religious framework; they, too, were imbued with a spiritual purpose, subtly guided by religious imperatives. The Ulema of the Ottoman medreses embraced the view that resistance to logic and mathematics was ultimately futile, as these disciplines sharpened the mind and facilitated the revelation of divine truths—truths that resonated with the essence of the divine. İnalcık further underscores that the study of philosophy was permitted only insofar as it served to substantiate and reinforce Islamic doctrines. Consequently, madaris were not merely educational institutions; they were bastions of religious education, deeply embedded in the Ottoman worldview. While scholars like Goffman have posited that the Ottoman Empire was characterized by a remarkable degree of tolerance and pluralism, the educational institutions at its core were staunchly religious, their curricula meticulously tailored to align with Islamic teachings. This religious-centric approach was not unique to the Ottomans; a parallel can be drawn with European practices of the early modern period. Jewish children, for example, learned Hebrew letters and basic prayers at home before advancing to synagogue-organized schools for Torah study. Similarly, Protestants were keen on imparting "proper religious values." Such parallels highlight a shared paradigm across cultures, where education was intimately linked with religious instruction. Yet, they encountered formidable obstacles when they audaciously attempted to seize the territories held by the English monarchy in the sun-drenched, rolling landscapes of southern France. The Jurassic Period, a significant segment of the Mesozoic Era, spans approximately from 201.3 ± 0.2 to 145.0 million years ago. This period is marked by substantial geological and paleontological developments. During the early Jurassic, the supercontinent Pangaea underwent significant tectonic activity, leading to its division into two distinct landmasses: the northern supercontinent Laurasia and the southern supercontinent Gondwana. This continental breakup facilitated the opening of the Gulf of Mexico, specifically within the nascent rift separating North America from the present-day Yucatan Peninsula of Mexico. The Jurassic North Atlantic Ocean remained relatively narrow during this time, while the South Atlantic did not begin to form until the subsequent Cretaceous Period, coinciding with the further fragmentation of Gondwana. Concurrently, the closure of the Tethys Sea saw the emergence of the Neotethys basin. Climatic conditions during the Jurassic were predominantly warm, with no substantial evidence of glaciation, indicating the absence of landmasses near the polar regions and a lack of extensive ice caps. 

The geological record of the Jurassic is notably well-preserved in western Europe, characterized by extensive marine sequences that suggest much of the continent was submerged under shallow, tropical seas. This is exemplified by renowned sites such as the Jurassic Coast World Heritage Site and the late Jurassic lagerstätten of Holzmaden and Solnhofen, which provide invaluable insights into the period's marine biodiversity and sedimentary environments.
